wikitext.*:
[[File:Ted Nasmith - Tuor at Vinyamar (swan).jpg|frame|Excerpt from ''[[:File:Ted Nasmith - Tuor at Vinyamar.jpg|Tuor and Vinyamar]]'' by [[Ted Nasmith]]]]
{{quote|...the proudest of all these birds were the swans.|''[[The Book of Lost Tales Part One]]'', "[[The Coming of the Elves and the Making of Kôr]]"}}

'''Swans''' were waterfowl of either black or white colour,<ref>{{FR|II9}}</ref> though usually the latter. It said that swans were especially abundant in the ''Nîn-in-Eilph'' ([[Swanfleet]]), a wetland region in [[Eriador]].<ref>{{RK|Partings}}</ref><ref>{{UT|Galadriel}}, "Appendix D: The Port of Lond Daer" (discussion of the name ''Glanduin'')</ref>

==History==
[[File:Anke Eißmann - Following The Swans.jpeg|thumb|right|''Following the Swans'' by [[Anke Eißmann]]]]
The swan was an important bird in the tales of the [[Elder Days]]. The [[Maiar|Maia]] [[Ossë]] sent "''many strong-winged swans''" to draw the ships of the [[Teleri]] over [[Belegaer]] to [[Aman]] without help of the winds. The Teleri (who were later called by the epithet the ''Swanherds'')<ref>{{MR|P3I3}} (§30)</ref> thus especially came to revere swans, and named their city [[Alqualondë]] (the Swanhaven) and built their [[Swan-ships|ships in swan-form]].<ref>{{S|5}}</ref><ref>{{SM|Q3}}</ref><ref>{{MR|P3I5}}</ref>

Ossë's master [[Ulmo]], the [[Vala]], sent seven great swans to guide [[Tuor]] to [[Vinyamar]], where he found a shield which had "an emblem of a white swan's wing". Tuor already loved these birds, having been fostered at [[Mithrim]], where swans seem to have been plentiful (and Tuor's foster-father, [[Annael]] and [[Elves of Mithrim|his folk]], had the swan as a symbol). Departing from Vinyamar, Ulmo's seven swans approached Tuor and offered him one feather each, which Tuor set in the crest of his helm.<ref>{{S|23}}</ref><ref>{{UT|1}}, pp. 25-28</ref>

The Teleri were not alone in using the swan-form in ship-building: the prow of [[Eärendil]]'s ship [[Vingilótë]] "''was fashioned like a swan''",<ref>{{FR|Meetings}}, "''[[Eärendillinwë]]''"</ref> and the Elves of [[Lothlórien]] made a [[Swan-ships|Swan-ship]], so well crafted that it resembled a real, giant swan.<ref>{{FR|Farewell}}</ref> 
[[Image:Ted Nasmith - Farewell to Lórien.jpg|thumb|right|''Farewell to Lórien'' by [[Ted Nasmith]]]]
In the [[Third Age]], the symbol of the [[swan-knights]] of [[Dol Amroth]] was a banner, silver upon blue, bearing a "token of the [[Ship and the Silver Swan]]", and their mariners used swan-prowed ships.<ref>{{RK|MT}}</ref><ref>{{RK|Siege}}</ref><ref>{{RK|Cormallen}}</ref>

==Other names==
In [[Sindarin]], the name for "swan" was ''[[alph]]'' (pl. ''eilph''), as in [[Nîn-in-Eilph]]. The [[Quenya]] [[Wikipedia:Cognate|cognate]] was ''[[alqua]]'', as in [[Alqualondë]], and the [[Telerin]] was ''[[alpa]]''.<ref>{{UT|Galadriel}}, "Appendix D: The Port of Lond Daer" (Note to discussion of the name ''Glanduin'')</ref>

In Tolkien's early tongues [[Ilkorin]] and [[Danian]], the name for "swan" was ''alch'' and ''ealc'', respectively.<ref>{{LR|Etymologies}} (entry [[ÁLAK|ÁLAK-]])</ref> Other early conceptions include [[Gnomish]] ''alfa'' or ''alfuil'' and [[Qenya]] ''alqe''.<ref>{{PE|11}}, pp. 18-19</ref>

==Other versions of the legendarium==
A fragment of an [[Tal-Elmar (chapter)|unfinished story]] mentioned a possibly fictitious race known as the [[Swans of Gorbelgod]].<ref>{{PM|XVII}}, p. 426</ref>

In an early version of the [[legendarium]], more details about the use of swans in symbolism and crafting are given:
*Reminiscent of the Elven [[Swan-ships]], [[Aulë]] seems to have been the first to make "''great vessels like to the bodies of swans''".<ref name=LT1>{{LT1|V}}, p. 124</ref>
*It is also said [[Tuor]] used a "''boat with a prow fashioned like to the neck of a swan''" on [[Lake Mithrim]], and that Ulmo apparently sent three swans to guide him out of Mithrim (much reminding of the later device of the "seven swans"). Later, the wing of a white swan became the symbol for Tuor and his company ([[House of the Wing]]) in [[Gondolin]].<ref>{{LT2|III}}</ref>
:''See also [[House of the Swan]]''

==Inspiration==
In a poem about [[Tom Bombadil]], it is said that Tom "''wore in his tall hat a swan-wing feather''".<ref>{{AB|Tom}}</ref> [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] explained in a letter to [[Pauline Baynes]] that the swan, (traditionally the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swan#Role_in_culture property of the King]), indicated a "''special friendship with Tom''", the swans being among the creatures "''who looked for the return of their rightful Lord, the true King''".<ref>{{L|240}}</ref> Perhaps this perceived nobility of the swans explains why Tolkien used the bird as a symbol for the princely line of Dol Amroth, and why the swans were described as allies of the [[Ainur]] and [[Elves]].

A glimpse of Tolkien's childhood experience with swans has also been described: 

{{blockquote|...they [Ronald and Hilary] would scamper away from the yard, and run round to a place behind the mill [at [[Sarehole]]] where there was a silent pool with swans swimming on it.|[[Humphrey Carpenter]], ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]''}}

==Portrayal in adaptations==
===Swans in adaptations===
<gallery mode="traditional" widths="200px" heights="150px">
File:The Rings of Power (TV series) - Paper Swan-ship.png|A paper Swan-ship in the [[A Shadow of the Past|first episode]] of ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power]]''.
</gallery>

'''1982-97: ''[[Middle-earth Role Playing]]'':'''
:''Black Swans'' are conceived as quite ill-meaning creatures "''known to mob and overturn boats''", and being larger than normal swans. Another type of swans, the ''Pied Swans'' (given the name ''Elph Tithen'' in Sindarin), are described as "''creamy white in color, liberally splotched and speckled with black and grey''", and said to be intelligent and friendly to travellers.<ref>{{ICE|8005}}</ref><ref>{{ICE|2012}}</ref><ref>{{ICE|8020}}</ref>

'''2022: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power]]'':'''
:'''September 1: ''[[A Shadow of the Past]]'':'''
::A group of Elf children are seen playing before watching a young [[Galadriel]] build a paper ship. When Galadriel sets the ship to float down a river, the paper changes its shape to that of a [[Swan-ships|swan]]. However, the Elf children cause it to sink by throwing stones at it, resulting in Galadriel attempting to attack them, only to be prevented by her older brother, [[Finrod]], who pulls the Swan-ship from the river with his dagger.
